column5: *Met the expectations
I'm thinking that donation bucket will not be overflowing considering the kerfuffel created by being forced to purchase poultry products and bait in Canada.

So.......if a person that lives in Fort Francis decides to take a trip over the bridge for .....oh lets say wing night (chicken) at a local restaurant in IFalls, and then heads back home to Fort Francis ! Is that considered bringing Poultry over the border ? Because you and me both know " you aint holding them wings very long" 🤣

Hold on, I thought we established Canada had chickens…….do they only have laying hens so the reason for the border crossing for wings???? I am so confused by all of this now!!!The new commercial coming is a chicken holding a sign that says “Eat Mor Beef”!!!😁
They call grouse chickens so yes they do have plenty chickens.
Maybe toll gates like in ill
To The Top click on the link for the bulletin.

Well said! I'm packed up and waiting for iceout. I been making the trip for over 20 years, and have never experienced anything but the utmost courtesy and professionalism. I'm pushing 70, and got my 4 pokes so I'm good to go. I live on hard-boiled eggs while travelling so hope that won't be a problem.

N of Quibeell………just be sure you don’t have any egg yoke on your teeth or cracked shells laying around the cab of your vehicle or the border boys might make you unpack your gear and then perform cavity searches on the members of your traveling caravan!!!!Good Luck

Good point. LOL. Years ago, when my wife was along, the Customs folks "tossed" our pickup. (Apparently there are teams that travel from station-to-station doing this.) They had a lot of fun when they found the "suspicious" bag of corn starch that the wife had packed for cooking. We all had a good laugh, and that was that.
Most of my travels have been on Hwy 502. Evidently we need to increase the tax then.
The Great Canadian Pothole ...just consider them as part of your wilderness experience that you can share with your great grandchildren.
I bet the famous French toast will be even more famous after using Canadian eggs. PjShorthorn
LMAO I'm going to find out in July. PjShorthorn
502 is better than any highway in Illinois.

I'd love to see voluntary collections set up by governments for this very issue (not saying it would replace taxation). For instance, at the border crossing the patrol can ask what direction/road we are traveling, and then inform us of an opportunity to make a road repair and maintenance donation. Put up one of those displays that shows how much has been collected. I include MN roads as well, loaded w travelers just passing through the state on the way to or from Canada. I know I'd happily kick in some dough as I'm sure many would.

Shorthorn,To be clear it is “famous award winning” French Toast!!!! Yes, I was concerned when I first saw this post but was relieved to find out that, yes, the Ontario’ins actually have laying hens and will have eggs available in local grocery stores! I thought for a minute I was going to have to get creative with some frozen french toast that clearly would not have the expectations of the group!!!!
Raw egg would have to be commercially pasteurized and packaged to bring them into Canada.
a 6 page thread on eggs. JUST BUY YOUR EGGS IN CANADA FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!!!!

My host is Canadian born (so I am assuming Canadian or dual), and he employs Canadians. We pay $1500 (yes, USD) per person, so $6000 per week. Add in $200+ for bait, $400+ for hotel rooms on either side of the trip, fuel (as you pointed out), licenses and outdoor cards, Canadian beer, $300 for misc restaurants also before and after, then throw in t-shirts, mugs, tourist crap that we bring back home as small gifts. This doesn't include whatever fees gets paid to the Winnipeg airport on the 50% of trips we take that we fly in there. On those trips we also buy all our groceries in Canada and rent our cars there as well. So it's going to come to a little bit more than a tank of gas. Just a little bit. It's worth every penny, but having another ridiculous regulation imposed is just another cut in the death by a thousand. We bring freeze dried eggs as it is a lot easier/convenient and less weight to do so, and now that is out. My patience with all things government-mandated is at an all time low. We support as many of the small businesses that we can in Red Lake. That has to be a tough place to make a living the last two years.I'm not alone in being annoyed with nonsense legislation. Can't bring preserved baits, have to show vaccine cards (proof of recent infection isn't adequate because... well...legislation, not science), and now additional restrictions on the ability to bring in convenience food items. If someone could tell me how USDA approved poultry items is more of a risk than wild birds flying across the border, I'll quit my whining.

I get annoyed also BUT!once your up there and spanking fish most of hassle goes away,forgotten,nobody said life is going to be cake walk and it ain't that's for sure,you'll still enjoy it when your up there even though there are more hurdles,good luck.

Impossible to control A.I.V. in wild birds,however safeguards can be implemented to control the spreading of the virus into the poultry flocks ...so that you can keep on enjoying your gourmet scrambled eggs. I support any government legislation that protects the citizens of their country. More gracious Canadian advice for you...Don't go trying to give a Bald Eagle a hug.
Focus on this Amigo. You're doing them a world of good by coming. That's how we feel.
"We support as many of the small businesses that we can in Red Lake." Yes....as do we. We buy all out groceries up there as well as our beer and rum. Got to support the locals of Red Lake area.
And don't forget about that GST/HST tax that we all love to pay.
Welll One of many things those taxes pay for are the long remote highways you drove on to get fishing.

Can’t wait to visit the beautiful Canadian wilderness again this Summer. We made a Sept trip last year when things opened. A few dozen eggs or chicken wings sure the **** are not going to keep us from our trip North this year! The outfitters, bait shop owners, beer shop keepers and the many others in Ontario we come in contact could not be any nicer and welcoming! Always have looked at it as a blessing that they share their beautiful country with others and always welcome us with open arms eggs or no eggs!!!! 😎
It would probably be a winning marketing strategy, and thanks for suggesting it, but in reality without a few conspiracy theorists in camp there would be a lot less to laugh about!

I always buy my eggs up there anyway. I do not bring any poultry. I have no problem with whatever the border rules are. I will follow them and enjoy the beauty, fishing and the fine people of Canada for the 10 days I get the privilege of being in there country for a bit.
Thankyou for your respectful attitude and I hope you have a great 10 days and have many more great memories to share with your family and friends.

I once knew a girl from Des Moines, Iowa that could swallow a dozen eggs without breaking the shell. She wasn't a real looker, weighed about 450ish, 6 felony dwi, ,oh well way to much work for a dozen eggs. But if she could swallow 40 dozen salted shiners, she have a place in my boat.

I guess if bait and eggs are the only things I have to worry about, I'll be fine. There is a general store about a mile from our resort anyway. We ordered our crawlers ahead of time last year and picked them up on our way threw. I'll just add 2 dozen eggs to the order and be good to go.

Would it be ok to say buy the eggs here in the states and bring them into Canada not in the shell buy in a frozen zip lock bag? We used to do this when egg prices were as low as $0.60 a dozen in the Chicago area years ago. The frozen eggs were easier to transport, and you never had to worry about them breaking on the drive up. Just asking.

In my opinion anything poultry isn't worth the hassle. You know they are going to ask you if you have anything poultry when your in line at the border. I have chickens at home that lay eggs. I love pickled eggs. I can buy some up there and make pickled eggs our first night there. They will be good to eat in a day or two. In my opinion it's not worth the hassle.
It has always been that way for any banned products including bait. PjShorthorn
Sounds to me like you would need a much bigger boat with her along.

I saw that last year when we were in line. A border officer was going truck to truck asking about bait. We saw a truck get out of line and go back across the bridge. I asked the officer when he came back threw and he said they sent the guy back to minnesota to discard his illegal bait. That's why I say anything to do with poultry is not worth trying to cross with. It's way easier to get the eggs when I get there than to be turned around at the border. Good luck to all.
Just have to wait n see what's next,dont you like surprises cheeks??

and I remember when I could cross into Sault Michigan to go bowling with just my drivers license and not need a passport. I remember when , our potatoes were allowed in the USA, I remember when my daughter went to University in Sault Michigan and drove back and forth every day without delays......I remember a simpler time , and then 911 happened in addition to diseases in beef and poultry and potatoes, etc etc. Both countries are doing what they think is best to mitigate the risks with the things they can control somewhat. Adapt or get upset,
I don't mind leaving the egg yokes home,but I wish we could bring the white part in so I can make my meringue for the pie,oh well.
Old age and death. Enjoy it while you can!

Sorry. My tongue in cheek response to being called a whiner for pointing out that the king-has-no-clothes is apparently lost on the king's fanboys. BTW, the US is no better on this than Canada... we too prohibit importation of agricultural products. Lotta good that does. For Immediate Release : Canada declares no American air may be brought over the border due to overwhelming risks of airborne contamination. All Americans must exhale prior to crossing the border, and deflate tires. Service stations selling overpriced and overtaxed (fair wages, dontcha know) Canadian air, worms, potatoes and eggs immediately available upon entrance. P.S. I checked with my outfitter. He said that he stands firmly on the side of Canadian policy, but as long as that means he can winter in Arizona and have access to the Mayo clinic for healthcare, he LOVES the sound of my whining as long as I bring stacks of US cash with me to enable his south of the 49th parallel endeavors.

Tourist dollars? Do you mean the one tank of gas you might be forced to purchase in Canada for the vehicle you are renting in the U.S.A which will be chock full of all your goodies you loaded up with before entering Canada. You are most likely supporting an American owned tourist camp operator which was probably paid for in the U.S.A. because that's what your types do. Being the gracious Canadian I am I will offer you this advice. Consider topping up tank in Prawda Manitoba. It's usuallly 10 to 15 Cents / litre cheaper there than in NWO.
What is next for you? Only Lib customers welcome?
Not only you can not bring chicken,etc. accross the border, instead of taking the chicken away, they are sending you back accross the border.
The old age is alright to enjoy,the death part not so much.Better get all the fishing in while your old.
Can you fella's put this on pause a minute ? I've got to pop some Orville Redenbacher's
Yeah, but you gotta love those shock absorbing seats !
Better to have a fat arse to absorb the bounce on a camp boat.
With a 9.9 there aint much bounce.
I always passed out before I would eat a bar egg or a ham hock. Canada has their own egg industry and is an exporter of eggs. During the last embargo eggs were cheaper in Canada compared to US.
Stay home then. We don't need any whiners on our lakes spoiling the call of the Loons.

Nah. I come up to specifically enhance your otherwise graceless existence with my tourist dollars and enlightened conservative values. I hold my nose and ignore your ridiculous over-reaching government nonsense. (It's getting easy since my own ridiculous over-reaching government has been drifting in that direction for years. Kinda a boiling-frogs thing.)
WOW.....what a ridiculous statement !!!! Please stay home , we prefer the respectable Americans that appreciate they are in a different country and enjoy it because we are endowed differently.
Well endowed!!
You're obviously a troubled man. I had hoped the vaccine requirment would result in a higher standard of guest coming north. Obviously there was a loop hole in your case.

Alot has changed in 30 years. I remember when we used to get our tax back that we paid on the cabin. We would stop at the Fort Francis duty free store and cash it in. I remember when we didn't need an outdoor card, i remember when we could cross with a Driver's license, i remember when we could take crawlers & frozen minners, i remember when we could take potatoes, i remember when we could take a couple dozen eggs to go with that delicious thick sliced Harvest bacon ! What's next fellas ?
I'd need to have a lot of chickens and about 100 dozen a day to make up a guide day.lol.Dont know if they allow the liquid eggs in but that stuff easier than eggs
I'm pretty sure I ate some dirt when the po po had my face smashed into the ground a cpl of times.
You still guide,your wife is retired,a new part time job,she be known as the egg lady along the road.double income.
Think we will stick to our day jobs
Probably good idea,easier than chasing chickens around.

Do you think a commercial product like "Egg Beaters" would be allowed? Those work fine for making fish batter and scrambled eggs . But they are definitely made out of items on the banned list. Feathers? Oh yeah, I do have feathers in the fly tying kit that I always bring with me. Suppose I better take those out because the border guard doesn't know they have been in there for 30 years.

Good God. More heavy handed nonsense. A much bigger threat are wild birds. Canadian government should require avian flu tests of all the geese that vacation down here in the states during the winter. But, of course, much like produce and bait, forcing us to purchase eggs and poultry products up there only helps (microscopically) their bottom line. Perhaps we should charge the Canadian government for all the free chow their geese dine on down here, or implement a goose poop tax. Canada sure seems h3ll bent on finding ways to dissuade US visitors.
I'm waiting for the day you cant bring your own boat 🤔
Shhh.... Bill
Nothing wrong with a 14 or 16ft camp boat with a 9.9,remember cheek it ain't the boat that catches the fish.

April 7, 2022 NEW RESTRICTIONS ON CHICKEN AND EGG PRODUCTS As per guidance by CFIA (Canada Food Inspection Agency), CBSA will be refusing entry of all live bird, bird products and by products. The link below provides more details as to what is allowed and not allowed, but examples are: eggs, yolks, egg whites (albumen) poultry meat (other than fully cooked, canned, commercially sterile meat products)CLICK ON THE LINK FOR CLARIFICATION! https://inspection.canada.ca/animal-.../1644937572682
Wonder what's the price gonna be for a dozen eggs up there?
Prov1800 buy a bunch of egg laying chickens and sell them along the hwy by your place,make some big arse money.
John's Poultry Shop, free eggs with any guided trip.
From what I read I think pickled eggs would be allowed. At least I hope so. If not oh well. It's one of my favorite snacks.
Exactly!
The only time I ate them was when I was drunk and didn't know any better hahaha,hope you can get them across,if not maybe they will allow pickled ostrich eggs i you can get ahold of those.

If it's the same as the last time they banned poultry, commercially packed pickled eggs that were still sealed were OK but home pickled eggs were not allowed. About 5 years ago a guy in our party argued with the Canadian border guys for quite a while trying to bring in the eggs he pickled.
What else did you eat that you didn't know about ? 🤣
